column5: A can of RAID for the dreaded outhouse. I know it is necessary, but being able to kill all the creepy crawlies is a godsend when the night descends. And to back it up with a good box of "huggies" to keep it clean. We also bring a box of cigars to help "smoke" things out in the outhouse after the "raid".

"Yard Guard" mosquito fogger works well inside and perimeter of the outhouse. Been carrying it for years for that purpose. Doesn't take much. Just don't set in it. Spiders are my biggest concern in the outhouse. I've had very slow healing spider bites on my arms and don't need one on the south forty.Pooch

Great....just great. After all these years I never really thought about creepy crawlers biting me on my hiney when in the outhouse. Now I'm not going to be able to get this out of my head for future trips. I'll be bringing a small propane torch and some vanilla scented candles. I hear spiders don't like vanilla scented candles. Add that to the list. PjShorthorn
Oh yea, I see that now. Just wondering too.
Ketchup! We forgot it once and fried potatoes just aren't the same without ketchup. Rain gear, sunscreen and bug spray.

[QUOTE=fishpoop;6197914]I Copy/paste from a couple of websites Quote: "Types of lime that have been used in outhouses include the following: Lime is calcium hydroxide (CaOH2), or more carelessly called S-lime or slaked lime. Quicklime is calcium oxide (CaO)." It's kind of a technicality, but calcium hydroxide is actually Ca(OH)2. It is also a caustic material, so make sure to handle with care and definitely avoid inhaling any of the dust.

In my younger years I would have responded....The Dancing Girls. With me being older, I don't have a whole lot of time to waste so now it is The Naked Dancing Girls. They normally fly in somewhere around day number 5 of a week long trip.... PjShorthorn
Sweet! So I'll have something to look forward to later in June then??? What about the blow up monkey?
Coleman Lantern and fuel- those propane lights are terrible-can't see to play cards.
Vaseline ........for obvious reasons. PjShorthorn

A good battery powered LED camp light like this:https://www.streamlight.com/en/produ...ndex/the-siegeI have two around the house for power outages and fishing trips. They are good lights. There are probably similar lights out there that are larger and cheaper, but.......... as good a quality?Pooch
Spam.
You for obvious reasons
extra socks and underwear baby wipes (to avoid swamp-***) Zantacs/Tums Extra Rod or two
Folding chair in a bag for shore lunch everyday
Baaaawwaaahahah. That's how we "roll" down south You need come on down here for the Georgia game this year. Plenty of room !!! PjShorthorn

That was a bit embarrassing to watch. Made me wonder what his wife's sample size was, saying he had the cleanest butt she had ever seen. Note to self, if I ever launch a youtube series and decide to discuss my TP preferences leave my wife out of it. FWIW, always took baby wipes when I went hunting over TP. All valid points he made, just a bit offputting.
Lip balm with at least SPF 15! And, I am in total agreement with the bum wipes!
We also bring a bag of powdered lime for the camp to put a few scoops down each outhouse hole to keep the smell down
Where do you get that? Is it like a cooking powdered spice?

I Copy/paste from a couple of websitesTypes of lime that have been used in outhouses include the following: Lime is calcium hydroxide (CaOH2), or more carelessly called S-lime or slaked lime. Quicklime is calcium oxide (CaO).tep 1Keep a covered, water-tight bucket of calcium hydroxide next to or inside the outhouse for easy access. Also known as hydrated lime, calcium hydrate, caustic lime or slaked lime, this product can be found at your local feed store.Step 2Dip a scoop, which should have a capacity of about one cup, into the lime and pour the lime into the outhouse hole after each use. Sprinkle the lime slowly and gently to avoid producing dust clouds or getting the substance on your skin or in your eyes, which causes burns. Likewise, avoid getting lime on the outhouse's seat.Step 3Repeat the process each time you put solid human waste into the outhouse or when odors become particularly strong. When applying more than a cup of lime to combat longstanding odors, wear work gloves, a face mask and safety goggles to protect yourself from clouds of lime dust.
I understand why you are taking it...BUT...if you ever get checked at the border, are you going to tell the border agents that story and better still, are they going to BUY it. Just sayin.
I was just answering the question from the poster above me. He wanted to know what kind of lime to use. As for crossing the border with it I have no knowledge.
everybody should know cpr
My son.
Ding Ding Ding.....we have a winner! And second prize goes to Diaper wipes, useful for many more reasons than the obvious.

Hi--one thing I have done over the past few years is to upgrade my old duffel bags to good, high-quality dry bags, and to upgrade the old plastic coolers to Yetis and Cabela's Polar Cap coolers.It's nice to have a good dry bag in the outpost boat to hold stuff like rain gear, extra sweatshirts, first aid kit, etc. Once you have had your gear and clothes soaked by rain or waves while loading or unloading for your outpost trip, you'll appreciate the insurance these dry bags give you.And worrying about meat and other perishables in a standard cooler while in the midst of a day+ flight delay due to fog, rain, etc., is no fun.Of course, it's easy to get carried away, and these things are expensive, but I look at them as investments. I never expect to have to replace them in my lifetime.

Just remember the weight of those coolers on a fly-in. I bought a bigger Coleman Marine cooler on sale last year and it works great for the couple days needed to get to the cabin. When the outfitter saw it he thought it was a Yeti or similar and he said they usually have to repack the stuff in his coolers for the flight. When I told him it was just a Coleman he was OK.
X10 A clean hiney is a happy hiney. PjShorthorn

I am sure many of you have seen this, but here is the reason for baby wipes. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=10lLPlhmytc That's four minutes of your life you will never get back, but sure is funny! Fish On! Hooks

Cleans Hands, Face, used for cleaning messes and can be used for tinder, besides the all important "maintenance" uses. Takes up less room than a roll, and comes moistened and it's OWN package. What's not to love!
That's fantastic LOL!
Sunblock! You can get absolutely fried if the weather is high and sunny. I carry a small stick of sunblock in the first aid kit ..... it gets used a LOT more than I thought it would.
Something you have to have on an outpost trip most people forget to bring, (aside from the obvious items)...??
nestea powdered iced tea!
Peppered Bacon
Some tools( adj wrench, vice grips) and a very good first aid kit.

Paring knife and fillet knife (of course). I'm particular about my knives I can do a lot with a fillet, but a great paring knife is a must. When I camped (back in the dark ages) I even carried a cast iron skillet.
you reminded me about something....i always bring my own chef knives on a trip....they come in really useful

Anything that shows you the day of the week, so you're not fishing 10 miles from your cabin on the day your plane shows up for your return flight. Six guys replaced us one year at Cobham River Outpost. They lost count of the days. Pete Cay showed up early Sunday morning to an empty cabin. Pete had a tight/full schedule and went to his next pickup.The six guys paid for a round trip from Red Lake to Cobham River Outpost, about 145 crow miles.
Immodium!!
One person in the group being up to snuff on CPR...and I'm not referring to catch, photo, release.
BABY WIPES.... For "obvious" reasons
